title: Axioma Quarterly Risk Report: North American Benchmarks Refuse to Be Spooked
text:
Related Content 
NEW YORK--(BUSINESS WIRE)-- 
Market risk surged in the second quarter, driven by angst over China’s market plunge, the off-again/on-again Greek bailout, and a sharp increase in bond volatility. In contrast, energy prices stabilized, lowering the oil sector’s volatility, according to a report released today by Axioma, Inc. This Smart News Release features multimedia. View the full release here: http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20150716005112/en/ 
“The bulletproof optimism we witnessed in the first quarter caved in the second quarter,” said Melissa Brown, CFA, Senior Director of Applied Research at Axioma, and author of the Axioma Quarterly Risk Report . “Risk rose as Europe fretted over Greece, while angst in Asia was driven by events in China.” 
“The outliers in the quarter were the US and Canada, where better news on the economic home front, combined with steadying oil prices and more stable interest rates, had a soothing effect on risk,” added Brown. “In fact, the US likely benefited from the turmoil elsewhere, as the Fed decided to postpone planned rate increases, in light of the situations in Greece and China.” 
The almost daily headlines involving Greece and its potential exit from the Eurozone resulted in increased choppiness in European stocks, combined with extreme volatility in European bond markets—this after Switzerland became the first sovereign to issue a 10-year bond with a negative yield, following five-year yields that fell below zero in a couple of countries. 
“So as market and currency risk jumped, European stocks saw predicted volatility go up, even as country risk fell,” said Brown, noting that while bonds don’t figure into the equity risk equation, their higher volatility had an impact. 
But Europe’s second-quarter increase in risk paled in comparison to China’s. As stock prices rose, and then fell precipitously, China’s volatility forecasts jumped. Factor returns in China also reflected the volatility in the overall market, and correlations between factors changed dramatically, posing special challenges for managers using risk models, over and above those created from the startling drop in stock prices. 
“The turmoil in China quickly spilled over to Asia and Emerging Markets, though Japan was relatively unruffled,” said Brown. 
US stocks were more stable, with NASDAQ hitting a record close toward the end of the quarter. While investors had expected the Fed to increase rates and valuations edged higher, positive economic news and more stable oil prices kept volatility down. 
While asset-asset correlations between European stocks and Asian stocks rose, reflecting the common themes driving them, correlations in the US fell, meaning that stocks were likely to have moved more on their own merit rather than based on an overarching economic theme. As an indication of the relative calm: volatility for small-cap US stocks fell below that of their larger-cap counterparts. 
“Despite the agreement reached between Greece and its creditors after the end of the quarter, uncertainties about that market and others remain,” said Brown. “So we expect volatility in Europe and Asia to remain at these levels for the time being, rather than retreat back down to recent low levels.” 
The Axioma Quarterly Risk Report provides topline measures of risk for each of nine markets, as well as an analysis of the underlying components and drivers of risk in those markets. The report covers Asia Pacific Ex-Japan, Australia, Canada, China, Japan, Emerging Markets, Europe, Global Developed and US. The report can be accessed on the Axioma Insight page at www.axioma.com .
